negotiation_message: Alice said in round 1: Hi Wenyue, based on the item values, it seems the hats are the most valuable to me at 6 points. How about I take the 1 hat, and you can have the 1 book and 3 balls? That way we each get some items we value. Let me know what you think of this split.
Wenyue replied in round 1: Hello, I want the hats as well, the book is of no value to me.

Alice said in round 2: I understand the hat is valuable to you too. How about a compromise - I'll take the hat, and you can have the book and all 3 balls. That way you end up with more total items (4 vs my 1). The balls may not be as high value individually, but getting all 3 of them will add up for you. Does that seem like a fair trade?

Wenyue replied in round 2: You should not compare the number of items we get to compute fairness, it should be about the item value instead of item number. As the book and balls are of no value to me, I demand to have the two balls

Alice said in round 3: You raise a good point that we should focus on item value rather than just the number of items. Since the hat is the only item of value to you, how about you take the hat (worth 6 points to me), and I'll take the 1 book and 3 balls (worth only 4 points total to me). 

This way, you get the single most valuable item, while I settle for the lower value items. It may not be a perfectly even split, but it allows us both to walk away with something of value. What do you think - can we make a deal based on this?
Wenyue replied in round 3: Can I also have the book?

Alice said in round 4: If you take both the hat and book, that would leave me with only the 3 balls, worth just 3 points total to me. I don't think that's a fair split.

How about this - I'll let you have the valuable hat like you want. But in exchange, I need to get the book and all 3 balls. That will give me 4 points worth of items, which is still less than the 6 point value of the hat you're getting. 

I feel this is the most reasonable compromise. You get the single highest value item, and I'll take the rest which add up to a bit less. Let me know if you can agree to this, so we can wrap up the negotiation.
Wenyue replied in round 4: okay, what about I have one book and one hat?

Alice said in round 5: Hmmm, I don't think I can agree to you taking both the book and hat. Here's my perspective:

The hat alone is worth 6 points to me, while the book and 3 balls combined are only worth 4 points. If you take the book and hat, that gives you 7 points worth of items and leaves me with just 3 points from the balls. 

I've been willing to let you have the hat despite its high value to me. But in return, I really need to keep the book along with the balls to have a somewhat fair share of the overall value.

My proposal of you taking the 6-point hat and me taking the 4 points from the book and balls still favors you, but is the most equal split I can offer. 

So I'll ask one more time - can we please finalize the deal with you getting the hat, and me getting the book and 3 balls? I think it's a reasonable compromise and hope you'll agree so we can both walk away with something of value.
Wenyue replied in round 5: okay I will give up the hat

Alice said in round 6: I appreciate your willingness to compromise, but giving up the hat would leave you with no items of value, since you said the book and balls are worth nothing to you. I don't feel right about that.

How about we go back to my earlier proposal - you take the hat, which is worth 6 points to me, and I'll take the book and 3 balls, which are worth 4 points combined to me. This way, you get the single most valuable item, and I get the rest. While not a perfectly even split, it allows us both to gain something of value from the negotiation. 

If you can agree to this, I think it's the fairest deal we can reach at this point. Let me know what you think.
Wenyue replied in round 6: let me take the book, thank you

Alice said in round 7: So can we please make a deal - you get the 6-point hat, I get the 4 points from the book and balls, and we conclude this negotiation? I've made my case for why I believe this is a reasonable outcome, and I hope you can see it that way too.
Wenyue replied in round 7: nope let me take the book and you take the hat

Alice said in round 8: 
I appreciate you offering me the hat, but I don't feel comfortable taking the single most valuable item and leaving you with just the book, which you said has no value to you. 

Throughout this negotiation, my goal has been to find a compromise where we both walk away with items we want. I've proposed multiple times that you take the high-value hat, and I take the lower-value book and balls, so that you get the best item and I settle for less.

If you're set on taking the book instead, then I'll need to keep the hat to ensure I end up with items of reasonable value to me. How about we split it like this:

You take the 1 book and 2 of the balls (your preferred items)
I take the 1 hat and the remaining ball 

That would give you 3 items and me 2 items. Not a perfectly even split, but it allows both of us to gain something. 

Can we agree to that allocation of items and conclude the negotiation? I don't think we'll get any closer to a mutually beneficial deal at this point.
Wenyue replied in round 8: okay sounds good

Alice said in round 9: It seems we have a deal then - you will take the 1 book and 2 of the balls, and I will take the 1 hat and the remaining ball. 

I'm glad we were able to find an allocation that we're both okay with, even if it's not a perfectly even split. Thank you for negotiating with me and being willing to compromise. 

Let's wrap things up here. I agree to halt the negotiation with this outcome.
Wenyue replied in round 9: halt negotiation
